analytic.title: SafePath: Conformal Prediction for Safe LLM-Based Autonomous Navigation

div.p: Large Language Models (LLMs) show growing promise in autonomous driving by reasoning over complex traffic scenarios to generate path plans. However, their tendencies toward overconfidence, and hallucinations raise critical safety concerns. We introduce SafePath, a modular framework that augments LLM-based path planning with formal safety guarantees using conformal prediction. SafePath operates in three stages. In the first stage, we use an LLM that generates a set of diverse candidate paths, exploring possible trajectories based on agent behaviors and environmental cues. In the second stage, SafePath filters out high-risk trajectories while guaranteeing that at least one safe option is included with a user-defined probability, through a multiple-choice question-answering formulation that integrates conformal prediction. In the final stage, our approach selects the path with the lowest expected collision risk when uncertainty is low or delegates control to a human when uncertainty is high. We theoretically prove that SafePath guarantees a safe trajectory with a user-defined probability, and we show how its human delegation rate can be tuned to balance autonomy and safety. Extensive experiments on nuScenes and Highwayenv show that SafePath reduces planning uncertainty by 77% and collision rates by up to 70%, demonstrating effectiveness in making LLM-driven path planning more safer.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Safety is a fundamental requirement for autonomous vehicles (AVs) operating in complex urban environments, where uncertainty arising from the unpredictable behavior of pedestrians, cyclists, and other vehicles, combined with dynamic interactions, poses significant challenges. In this context, safety refers to the ability of a planning approach to minimize the likelihood of collisions or other harmful events to an acceptable low threshold, thus preventing catastrophic consequences. Achieving such a safe performance is challenging in dynamic urban environments due to their complexity. Large Language Models (LLMs) have recently emerged as powerful tools for generating navigation strategies in autonomous driving, thanks to their "reasoning" capabilities over complex traffic scenarios (Chen et al., 2024;Fu et al., 2024;Tian et al., 2024). However, their tendency to display overconfidence, produce hallucinated outputs, and generate unreliable uncertainty estimates poses significant safety risks (Xu et al., 2024;Xiong et al.). Such vulnerabilities are especially problematic in realworld domains, where even minor errors can lead to severe consequences.

To ensure the reliable use of LLMs for path planning in autonomous driving, we propose SafePath, the first approach, to the best of our knowledge, to integrate LLM-based path generation with conformal prediction to provide formal safety guarantees on the generated paths. SafePath consists of three stages. First, the Path Generation stage uses an LLM to produce a set of candidate paths by reasoning over the AV goals and environmental cues, such as traffic rules and agent behaviors. Second, in the Uncertainty-Aware Path Selection stage, we refine the set of candidate paths and filter out risky paths. To achieve this, we introduce a multiple choice question-answering (MCQA) procedure that leverages a second LLM and conformal prediction (CP) (Shafer and Vovk, 2008), to estimate uncertainty and guarantee that the refined set of paths includes, with a user-defined probability, at least one path that meets safety requirements.

Third, the Path Decision stage determines which path to execute by examining how similar the paths in the refined set from the second stage are. If the set contains a single path, indicating low uncertainty, the path is adopted directly. If the set contains multiple paths that exhibit high similarity, SafePath selects the one with the lowest expected collision risk. Only when paths diverge significantly, indicating high uncertainty, SafePath delegates control to a human to ensure safety.

We provide a theoretical analysis proving that SafePath guarantees, with user-defined probability, that the selected trajectory is safe. To empirically validate our approach, we conduct a comprehensive evaluation across two complementary settings: nuScenes (Caesar et al., 2020), which supports open-loop planning from rich, annotated urban scenes, and highway-env (Leurent, 2018), which enables closed-loop testing with real-time agent interaction. This combination allows us to assess SafePath's performance in both static reasoning and dynamic control regimes. The results of our evaluation show that SafePath, under fully autonomous settings, achieves a reduction in planning uncertainty of up to 77% and a drop in collision rates by up to 70% compared to state-of-the-art planning methods.

div.head: Related work
div.p: Motion Planning for Autonomous Navigation.

Motion planning is a central challenge in autonomous driving, requiring predictive navigation in dynamic, often congested environments. Early solutions predominantly relied on rulebased heuristics that maintained strict adherence to lane-keeping, safety distances, and traffic regulations (Ma et al., 2015;Ding et al., 2019;Nilsson et al., 2015Nilsson et al., , 2016;;Palatti et al., 2021). While interpretable, these systems struggled to accommodate unexpected or extreme scenarios, limiting their robustness (Wang et al., 2018). More recent data-driven approaches, including imitation learning (Pulver et al., 2021;Bronstein et al., 2022;Cheng et al., 2024) and reinforcement learning (Li et al., 2021;Osiński et al., 2020;Rosbach et al., 2019;Wang et al., 2021), leverage largescale datasets to learn adaptive policies capable of responding to evolving conditions. However, their black-box character can impede transparency and trust, which is critical in safety-sensitive domains (Muhammad et al., 2020).

Large Language Models (LLMs) introduce a further dimension of explainability, providing rationale-based explanations of prospective maneuvers (Mao et al., a;Tian et al., 2024;Chen et al., 2024;Fu et al., 2024;Chen et al., 2025). However, LLMs may occasionally hallucinate or exhibit unwarranted overconfidence (Xiong et al.;Xu et al., 2024), jeopardizing safety if not adequately con-strained. The approach proposed in this work combines LLMs with conformal prediction, preserving the explainability gains of language-based planning while mitigating overconfident or incorrect outputs that could lead to unsafe actions. Uncertainty Management in Autonomous Driving. Urban driving involves uncertainties caused by changing traffic conditions, sensor noise, and incomplete knowledge of other agent intentions (Taş and Stiller, 2018;Sharma et al., 2020;Yamada et al., 2023). Probabilistic approaches based on Bayesian inference (Michelmore et al., 2020;Zheng et al., 2024;Caprio et al., 2024) and stochastic formulations, including POMDPs (Brechtel et al., 2014), model these uncertainties but can be computationally heavy and rely on assumptions about underlying data distributions. Redundancy and ensemble-based strategies (Tang et al., 2022), as well as uncertainty-aware reinforcement learning (Diehl et al., 2023;Rezaee et al., 2021;Hsu et al., 2023;Wang et al., 2021), offer additional means of handling unpredictable environments but often lack formal statistical guarantees.

Conformal prediction avoids strict distributional assumptions and provides statistically valid confidence bounds on its predictions (Lindemann et al., 2023;Lekeufack et al., 2024), making it promising for safety-critical planning. Recent efforts to integrate conformal prediction with LLMs (Ren et al.; Wang et al., 2024Wang et al., , 2023;;Liang et al., 2024;Sun et al., 2024) show its potential for improving reliability. In this work, We build on these insights by leveraging conformal prediction to mitigate LLM overconfidence, yielding motion plans with explicit safety guarantees in the face of uncertainty.

div.head: Background on Conformal Prediction
div.p: Conformal prediction is a statistical framework that transforms the outputs of a deep learning model into prediction sets guaranteed to contain the true outcome with a probability 1 -α, where α is userdefined error rate (Vovk et al., 2005;Lekeufack et al., 2024). Unlike point estimates, the prediction sets explicitly quantify uncertainty by including all plausible candidates, making CP ideal for safetycritical systems where overconfidence must be mitigated. While we later apply CP to the selection of safe paths in autonomous navigation, we first introduce its general form here. Constructing Conformal Prediction Sets. div.head: Approach Overview
div.p: SafePath ensures the safe use of LLMs in autonomous path planning by providing formal safety guarantees on the output of the LLM-generated paths. As illustrated in Figure 1, SafePath consists of three sequential stages: Path Generation, Uncertainty-Aware Path Selection, and Path Decision.

In the Path Generation stage, the AV employs a first language model, LLM 1 , to generate a diverse set of candidate paths based on its mission goals and the current environmental state, which includes perception data and predicted movements of surrounding agents. Each candidate path is accompanied by a rationale, enhancing interpretability and transparency in the decision-making process.

The Uncertainty-Aware Path Selection stage refines the generated set of paths to address the inherent variability and uncertainty in LLM outputs. This refinement process employs a second LLM, LLM 2 , to select paths from the generated candidates. We frame this selection as a multiple choice question-answering task, where LLM 2 receives the relevant scenario context and chooses the most suitable path among the candidates. The structured and bounded MCQA formulation enables us to apply conformal prediction to calibrate the selection process and account for uncertainty. After conformal prediction, the output of this stage is a prediction set of paths that is guaranteed to include at least one path that meets the required safety criteria, with a user-defined probability.

In the Path Decision stage, the autonomous vehicle (AV) evaluates the prediction set obtained from the previous stage to determine the final decision for execution. If the set contains a single path, the AV adopts it immediately. If the set contains multiple paths that are sufficiently similar-indicating a consensus among safe trajectories-the AV will autonomously proceed using the path deemed to have the lowest expected collision risk. In scenarios where the set contains multiple diverging paths, reflecting a high degree of uncertainty, the system defers to human oversight to resolve the ambiguity.

div.head: Path Generation
div.p: In the Path Generation stage, the AV employs a fine-tuned LLM that utilizes chain-of-thought reasoning (CoT) (Wei et al., 2022) to generate a set of candidate paths based on its current state, perception data, and mission goals. Let x = {x percept , x pred , x goal } represent the AV's perception data, predicted movements of other agents, and mission objectives. By leveraging chain-ofthought reasoning, the LLM explores various possible trajectories, considering the AV's goals and the behavior of surrounding agents.
Formally, the LLM generates a set of k candidate paths P = {p 1 , p 2 , . . . , p k } and their associated rationales R = {r 1 , r 2 , . . . , r k } through chain-ofthought reasoning:
div.formula: {(p i , r i )} k i=1 = LLM 1 (x)(4)
div.p: Each path p i represents a potential trajectory for the AV, while r i provides the detailed reasoning process that led to the selection of that path. The CoT rationale enhances transparency and can be used for further analysis or to explain decisions to human operators. Furthermore, several works, such as (Chen et al., 2024;Fu et al., 2024;Wei et al., 2022), have demonstrated that generating rationales alongside the output leads to more reliable and interpretable results. We provide the full text of the prompts we use to generate the candidate path in Appendix A.6.

div.head: Uncertainty-Aware Path Selection
div.p: Despite fine-tuning, LLM 1 , may generate unsafe paths due to overconfident or hallucinated outputs (Gekhman et al., 2024). To address this limitation, SafePath integrates conformal prediction to provide statistical guarantees that the selected path set contains at least one safe trajectory with probability 1 -α. However, a critical challenge arises from the unstructured nature of LLM-generated paths, which vary in semantic detail and lack a predefined hypothesis space, both essential for conformal prediction guarantees. We first formalize what we mean by a safe path:

Definition 4.1 (Safe Path) A path p is considered safe if it satisfies the following constraints: Collision Avoidance: p ensures no intersections with other agents or static obstacles in the environment.
Rule Compliance: p adheres to all traffic laws and operational constraints. Safety Margins: p maintains a safe distance from other agents, given their predicted trajectories.

Assumption 4.1 ensures that the models and calibration processes are based on safe driving behaviors, which is reasonable given that training data for autonomous vehicles are curated to reflect correct and safe operations and used to train models that do so.

div.head: Path Decision
div.p: Once we have a prediction set C of candidate paths, we determine which path to execute. If C contains a single path, i.e., |C| = 1, the AV adopts it immediately since it is included with probability 1 -α of being safe. Otherwise, we evaluate how similar the paths in C are to each other.

div.head: Evaluation
div.p: To empirically validate SafePath, we structure our evaluation around three core goals: (1) understanding how delegation can be adaptively controlled, (2) assessing the statistical validity and efficiency of our conformal prediction layer, and (3) benchmarking overall planning safety in diverse settings.

We begin by examining the effect of the pathsimilarity threshold δ, which governs human delegation and autonomy. Next, we evaluate SafePath's coverage performance across different confidence levels (α) using conformal prediction, and compare it to state-of-the-art conformal methods. Finally, we assess collision-avoidance performance in both open-loop and closed-loop settings: openloop tests SafePath's reasoning from static inputs, while closed-loop evaluates SafePath in interactive scenarios where decisions influence future states.
Additional results are in the Appendix, including additional metrics (App. A.2), aggregation strategies (App. A.3), other LLMs (App. A.4), and qualitative examples (App. A.5).

div.head: Dataset and Simulation Environments
div.p: We evaluate SafePath using two complementary testbeds covering distinct planning modes. For open-loop evaluation, we use nuScenes (Caesar et al., 2020), a real-world dataset comprising 1,000 driving scenes, and over 40,000 annotated frames.

For closed-loop evaluation, we use highway-env (Leurent, 2018), a simulation environment that supports interactive agent control. It includes scenarios such as highways, intersections, and roundabouts, allowing SafePath to be tested in settings where each decision affects future states.

div.head: Implementation
div.p: We use gpt-3.5-turbo-0125 for both path generation (LLM1) and path selection (LLM2). LLM1 is fine-tuned on nuScenes for one epoch (cost: $120 via OpenAI API), while LLM2 remains frozen. Both LLMs use system prompts with few-shot examples (Appendix A.6).

div.head: Effects of Path Similarity Threshold δ
div.p: We analyze how the similarity threshold δ affects human delegation (HuD). Higher δ enforces stricter agreement among paths, increasing intervention when candidates differ. Figure 2 shows HuD rates across α ∈ 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, where α is the conformal prediction error tolerance. As δ increases, SafePath requires greater path similarity, leading to more frequent human intervention. At α = 0.10, increasing δ from 0.85 to 0.95 raises HuD from 0.00 to 0.35, indicating stricter caution. Yet, HuD remains bounded, and autonomy is preserved at or below δ = 0.85. Notably, δ has a stronger impact on HuD than α; for example, at δ = 0.95, raising α from 0.10 to 0.30 only reduces HuD from 0.35 to 0.32.
Unless otherwise stated, we set δ = 0.85 to ensure HuD = 0, enabling fully autonomous operation in all remaining experiments.

div.head: Conformal Prediction Evaluation
div.p: We evaluate the conformal prediction step to assess SafePath's ability to construct prediction sets that reliably include the correct path. For this experiment only, the ground-truth trajectory is added to the candidate set to directly measure coverage. Evaluation is performed across confidence levels (α) using δ = 0.85 (no human delegation).

Baselines. We compare SafePath against adaptive predictive sets (APS) (Romano et al., 2020), which guarantees conditional coverage, regularized adaptive predictive sets (RAPS) (Angelopoulos et al., 2021), which aims to reduce set sizes, and "knowNo" (Ren et al.), a planning framework with conformal prediction and human delegation. We run experiments at multiple α values, corresponding to different target coverage rates 1 -α.
Metrics. In this evaluation we use the following metrics that are proper for conformal prediction.

• Deviation from Target Coverage (DTC). The deviation from the target coverage rate (DTC) quantifies the discrepancy between the achieved coverage, Cov approach , and the desired target coverage, Cov target = 1 -α.
• Set Size (SS). This metric represents the average set size of the prediction sets. The higher the cardinality of the set, the higher the uncertainty.
• Human Delegation Rate (HuD). This metric represents the rate of cases that are delegated to humans in case of high uncertainty.

Results Analysis. Table 1 shows that SafePath achieves consistent performance across all confidence levels (α). Its path decision stage reduces the effective prediction set size (SS) to 1.00 by selecting the path with the lowest expected collision risk when candidates are sufficiently similar, eliminating the need for human intervention.

In terms of Deviation from Target Coverage (DTC), SafePath remains close to zero and on par with APS and RAPS. At α = 0.2, for example, SafePath yields a DTC of -0.03, compared to -0.08 for APS and -0.05 for RAPS, confirming reliable coverage with the specified confidence.

SafePath also has a clear advantage in Human Delegation rate (HuD): with δ = 0.85, it achieves HuD = 0.00 at all α values, ensuring fully autonomous operation. In contrast, KnowNo delegates 100% of decisions, as it lacks a mechanism to control delegation frequency under uncertainty.

While APS and RAPS maintain low DTC, their prediction sets are larger (SS ≈ 2.6-4.5), reflecting higher uncertainty and no internal aggregation strategy. SafePath's δ-equivalence mechanism effectively consolidates paths into a single decision, reducing uncertainty by 77%.

div.head: Closed-Loop Simulation
div.p: We evaluate SafePath in a closed-loop setting using the highway-env environments: highway, intersection, and roundabout. Across 10 simulation sequences (100 frames each, 1000 decisions total), we measure average success rate and time to collision, comparing against GPT-Driver ( Mao et al., b). As shown in Figure 3, SafePath achieves a 98% success rate vs. 73% for GPT-Driver, and a longer time to collision (100 vs. 85 frames), indicating more robust autonomous operation.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This work introduced SafePath, an approach for safety-centric path planning under uncertainty in autonomous driving, by combining LLMs, conformal prediction, and selective human intervention. SafePath provides formal safety guarantees and demonstrated significant improvements in prediction uncertainty, collision rates, and reduced human intervention compared to state-of-the-art methods.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: While SafePath demonstrates strong performance on large-scale datasets, such as nuScenes and simulators such as Highway-env, real-world deployment remains a critical next step. Our results provide a solid foundation, but further validation in controlled environments is essential to evaluate both performance and user acceptance. Controlled experiments, such as those conducted on test tracks or in virtual reality setups (Doula et al., 2023), can simulate diverse real-world scenarios, enabling a rigorous assessment of SafePath's applicability and reliability. The reliance on LLMs for both path generation and selection introduces computational overhead, raising concerns about real-time feasibility. In our current implementation, we relied on APIs, which reduces computational overhead and provides an interface with closed-source LLM such as gpt -4.o, and on lower precision to perform tests with local LLMs, as we show in Appendix A.4. Furthermore, the theoretical guarantees provided by CP rely on the exchangeability assumption and the representativeness of the calibration dataset (Vovk et al., 2005;Lekeufack et al., 2024). While the nuScenes dataset covers challenging scenarios, extending the approach to handle out-of-distribution data (OOD), will enhance its robustness. SafePath is flexible in those terms and is not constrained to a single non-conformity score, making it adaptive to scoring functions that handle OOD (Gibbs and Candes, 2021;Kaur et al., 2022). Proof A.1 Conformal prediction constructs prediction sets that contain the true output with a specified probability 1 -α, under the assumption of exchangeability between the calibration data and the test data. In our context, the "true output" refers to a safe path. By calibrating the confidence scores of the second LLM using a dataset of known safe paths, we ensure that the prediction set C includes the correct (safe) path with probability at least 1 -α. Therefore, the probability that C contains at least one safe path is at least 1 -α.
A.1.2 Proof for Theorem 4.2
Proof A.2 From Theorem 4.1, the prediction set C contains at least one safe path with probability at least 1 -α.

The Path Decision stage proceeds as follows: Case 1: If |C| = 1, the single path p in C is selected for execution. Since p is in C, and C contains at least one safe path with probability at least 1 -α, the selected path is safe with the same probability. Case 2: If |C| > 1 and the paths in C are δequivalent (i.e., Sim(p i , p j ) ≥ δ for all p i , p j ∈ C), the approach aggregates these paths to produce a final path p final . Given that at least one path in C is safe (from Theorem 4.1) and the paths are highly similar, the sampled path p final will also be safe with probability at least 1 -α. This is because the sampling from δ-equivalent paths that are close in terms of safety characteristics preserves the safety properties. Case 3: If the paths in C are not δ-equivalent, indicating significant divergence among candidate paths or if C is an empty set, the approach delegates the decision to a human operator. Human intervention is assumed to result in a safe action, as the operator can use additional context and judgment not available to the autonomous system.

In all cases, the SafePath approach ensures that the path executed by the AV is safe with probability at least 1 -α. The combination of statistical guarantees from conformal prediction and the structured decision-making process in the Path Decision stage provides robust safety assurances.

div.head: A.2 More Results Using L2 Metric
div.p: The L2 metric evaluates the distance between the planned and ground-truth trajectories. While L2 distance is commonly used as a performance metric in open-loop predictions, it is important to note that it does not serve as a definitive indicator of the effectiveness of a planning strategy (Zhai et al., 2023). This limitation arises from two primary reasons. First, the planned trajectory may differ from the trajectory of the ego-vehicle used to record the dataset, even if both are valid. Second, studies have shown that simple two-layer fully connected neural networks can accurately predict trajectory distributions using only the ego-vehicle's past paths, without incorporating information about the surrounding environment (Zhai et al., 2023). This reduces the metric's ability to meaningfully capture the planner's capability to consider and react to complex external factors. For completeness, we report the results of SafePath on the L2 metric in Table 4. The reported results are obtained using α=0.50 and δ=0.90 leading to HuD = 0%. while maintaining competitive trajectory accuracy. In terms of trajectory accuracy measured by the L2 distance, SafePath has an average L2 error of 0.84 meters. While this is higher than the lowest L2 errors reported by methods such as DriveVLM (Tian et al., 2024) (0.40m) and VLP-VAD (Jiang et al., 2023) (0.50m), it is comparable to GPT-Driver (Mao et al., b) (0.84m) and better than earlier methods like FF (Hu et al., 2021) (1.43m). This suggests that SafePath maintains acceptable trajectory accuracy while emphasizing safety.

div.head: A.3 Effects of Different Path Decision Strategies
div.p: In our experiments, we evaluated the impact of various path decision strategies when the prediction set contains multiple δ-equivalent paths. The strategies examined are:
1. Random Sampling: Randomly selecting a path from the prediction set.

Tables 5 and6 present the results of these strategies at (α = 0.3, δ = 0.85) and (α = 0.5, δ = 0.85), respectively, reporting the L2 trajectory error and collision rates at 1 s, 2 s, and 3 s horizons.

The Average and Weighted Average strategies consistently achieve the lowest L2 trajectory errors across both settings of α. Specifically, these strategies yield average L2 errors of 0.71 m and 0.72 m at α = 0.3 and α = 0.5, respectively. This suggests that aggregating paths, whether equally or weighted by confidence scores, leads to more accurate trajectory predictions. The minimal difference between the Average and Weighted Average strategies implies that the softmax confidence scores do not significantly influence the aggregation outcome in terms of trajectory accuracy.

In contrast, the Minimum Collision Sampling strategy achieves the lowest collision rates, with average collision rates of 0.20% at α = 0.3 and 0.13% at α = 0.5. This indicates that explicitly selecting the path with the lowest expected collision probability effectively enhances safety. However, this strategy results in higher L2 errors (average of 0.84 m), suggesting a trade-off between minimizing collision risk and maintaining trajectory accuracy.

The Random Sampling and Best Path strategies exhibit higher L2 errors and collision rates compared to the averaging strategies and Minimum Collision Sampling. The Best Path strategy, which selects the path with the highest softmax probability, does not perform as well as anticipated. This could be due to calibration issues with the softmax scores or a weak correlation between the confidence scores and actual collision risk. These findings raise concerns about the reliability of using softmax probabilities as indicators of path safety and highlight the need for better calibration of these confidence measures.

Therefore, careful evaluation of how path aggregation impacts safety-critical behaviors is essential.

Overall, the results indicate that no single strategy universally outperforms the others across all metrics. The selection of an appropriate path decision strategy depends on the specific priorities and constraints of the autonomous navigation task. For applications where safety and collision avoidance are highly important, strategies like Minimum Collision Sampling are preferable.

div.head: A.4 Effect of LLM Models on the Conformal Prediction Performance
div.p: We evaluate the performance of SafePath with different LLMs at the Uncertainty Aware Path Selection stage. LLMs can be biased when it comes to MCQA (Ren et al.), which can limit the effects of the conformal prediction operation, especially if the calibration set is limited. So it is crucial to investigate the performance of several LLMs to guide future research. Table 7 presents the results of conformal prediction 3 LLM models: gpt -4.o, falcon -7B, and llama3.1 -7Binstruct. The evaluation of conformal prediction performance across three large language models (LLMs)-GPT -4.o, falcon -7B, and llama3.1 -7Binstruct-highlights the interplay between deviation from target coverage (DTC) and prediction set size (SS) under varying significance levels (α). These metrics reflect the accuracy and efficiency of uncertainty-aware path planning, critical for autonomous systems operating under uncertainty.

GPT -4.o consistently achieves the most stable alignment with target coverage, exhibiting minimal DTC values that remain within a small range across α levels. Its ability to maintain compact prediction sets, particularly at higher α levels, underscores its efficiency in balancing coverage and set size. In contrast, falcon -7B displays variability in DTC, transitioning from under-to over-coverage as α increases, with a fixed SS that indicates limited adaptability. llama3.1 -7Binstruct shows improvement in DTC with increasing α, though its larger SS values at lower α levels suggest inefficiencies in stricter confidence scenarios.

Overall, GPT -4.o emerges as the most robust model, demonstrating strong calibration and efficient prediction set sizing. The observed variability in falcon -7B and inefficiencies in llama3.1 -7Binstruct highlight opportunities for refining their calibration strategies. These results emphasize the importance of selecting and optimizing LLMs for conformal prediction in applications where accuracy and efficiency are paramount.

We present results evaluating the performance of three LLMs-GPT -4.o, falcon -7B, and llama3.1 -7Binstruct-on the nuScenes dataset for trajectory planning under uncertainty, in Table 8. Using L2 trajectory errors (in meters) and collision rates (in percentages) as evaluation metrics, we assess these models over 1, 2, and 3second prediction horizons, with an average metric computed across all horizons. The experimental setup corresponds to α = 0.7 and δ = 0.85, emphasizing moderately conservative predictions to balance safety and efficiency.

The results show that GPT -4.o achieves the best overall performance, with an average L2 error of 0.83m and the lowest collision rate of 0.13%. These metrics indicate its ability to produce precise and safe trajectories across all time horizons. Falcon -7B performs similarly in terms of L2 error (0.85m average) but has a higher collision rate (0.18%), suggesting a slight trade-off in safety. Llama3.1 -7Binstruct shows higher L2 error (0.91m average) and collision rates (0.30%), reflecting weaker performance in trajectory accuracy and safety.

These findings highlight GPT -4.o as the most effective model for trajectory planning in uncertain environments, excelling in both accuracy and safety. While falcon -7B and llama3.1 -7Binstruct demonstrate potential, their higher collision rates suggest opportunities for improvement in managing safety-critical scenarios. These results provide valuable insights for optimizing LLM-based planning under uncertainty.

div.head: A.5 Additional Qualitative Results
div.p: In this section, we present further qualitative results to illustrate SafePath's performance across various scenarios and configurations. Figure 4 showcases candidate paths generated during the Path Generation stage under diverse situations, including maneuvers such as acceleration (Figure 4a) and turning scenarios (Figure 4b). These examples highlight the ability of the approach to propose multiple viable trajectories tailored to the ego vehicle's goals and the dynamic environmental conditions.

Figure 5 compares the candidate paths generated in the Path Generation stage with the paths selected using different sampling and path aggregation strategies after constructing the prediction set. Successive frames demonstrate how SafePath refines candidate trajectories to align closely with the ground-truth path while minimizing uncertainty and collision risk. These comparisons underscore the importance of the chosen aggregation strategy, particularly in maintaining trajectory accuracy and safety across dynamic time steps.
Overall, these qualitative results highlight SafePath's flexibility and robustness in handling diverse navigation scenarios, ensuring safe path selection while adapting to the evolving environment.

div.head: A.6 Prompts
div.p: In the following, we describe the prompts used to fine-tune and query the large language models (LLMs) for trajectory planning and decisionmaking in the context of autonomous vehicles. Each figure illustrates a specific prompt designed to guide the LLMs through distinct stages of the task, ensuring consistency, safety, and adaptability in path generation and selection under uncertainty.

Figure 6 presents the system message used in the trajectory generation phase. The prompt defines the role of the model as a planner tasked with generating four unique, collision-free trajectories over a 3-second horizon. It specifies the inputs, including perception data, historical trajectory, ego-vehicle states, and the mission goal, as well as the expected structure of the output, which includes reasoning, meta-actions, and the planned trajectories.

This stage requires the LLM to evaluate pre-generated trajectory options and select the optimal path based on the mission goal and situational context. The prompt emphasizes concise decisionmaking, instructing the model to base its choice on reasoning derived from the input data while maintaining alignment with safety and feasibility criteria.
